metadata.name: Focussing Lightness #8
metadata.description:
In the depths of love, we search and find,
Connections that can truly bind,
Emotions run deep, and hearts entwine,
A smile, a hug, in love we confine.

Carnal pleasures may come and go,
But genuine affection, like rivers, flow,
Embrace the present, let worries fade,
In the warmth of love, our souls are made.

Sincere relationships, we seek to forge,
A path of happiness, our hearts to gorge,
In the light of others, we find our way,
From darkness and despair, we keep at bay.


Made in HydraSynth.

metadata.name: Agave & Patchwork #522
metadata.description:
Agave & Patchwork
---------------
Controls:
Press 1-6 to change the scale of the canvas (1 = default, 2000px x 2000px, 6 = 12,000px x 12,000px)
S: Save output at current size
F: Toggle fullscreen
Add the url params x and y to set custom dimensions. For example, add &x=1500&y=500 for a 1500px x 500px image
---------------
Tyler Boswell (@teaboswell) 2023
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: Enfantines II. Enfantillages Pittoresques #72
metadata.description:
The Enfantines¬†are three sets of beginner piano pieces by¬†Erik Satie, written with the aim of preparing children for the sound patterns of modern music. Composed in 1913, these are genuine children‚Äôs pieces, crafted for small hands, easy to learn. 

‚ÄúEnfantines II. Enfantillages Pittoresques‚Äù is the second of a set of algorithms that explore the basics of Generative Art, written with the aim of preparing artists for the script patterns of digital life. ‚ÄúEnfantillages Pittoresques‚Äù experiments with predefined plots, colour blending, webgl shaders, and generative music; all with a fresh, childish style. This algorithm has been trained to draw basic shapes in accordance to Satie‚Äôs lyrics. However, it uses them in unusual ways and creates what looks like fantastic creatures, microscopic beings, or, to follow Corneille, Constant, and Appel: "human animals".

‚ÄúIt took me four years to paint like Raphael, but a lifetime to paint like a child‚Äù Attributed to Picasso (falsely, probably)

With two modes that won‚Äôt produce the same outputs, ‚ÄúEnfantines‚Äù are best experienced twice. In music mode, the code uses Satie‚Äôs piano composition as a way of taming randomness, the sounds affecting the parameters of the strokes.

Hey, these have won me congratulations from the Shah of Persia and the King of Yvetot!


# INTERACTIVITY
Press M or Double Tap (mobile) for AUDIO mode
Wait for SILENT mode
Press I for Trait Info (desktop)
Press 1 for Canvas Save (desktop)

Introduce ‚Äú?pixelDensity=171‚Äù after URL for FULL SCREEN MODE (pseudo-deterministic).
Introduce ‚Äú?pixelDensity=X‚Äù for HQ renders (standard is 2, and 8 produces 400ppi 40x44cm prints).


# EASY-TO-READ CODE
The ‚ÄúEnfantines‚Äù are educational algorithms. The code has been compressed and minified for a performance boost, but can be read fully in GitHub: https://github.com/ratchitect/


# PERFORMANCE
Better experienced with Chrome.

metadata.name: QuadTubes - Abstract Variations #95
metadata.description:
This piece features abstract patterns created using an algorithm I call QuadTubes.

It works by continuously stroking a set of quadratic curves that run through a set of points while rotating those points along a constant orbit.

This piece features 13 different arrangements and 11 different colors sets, so there should be around 20 pieces of each arrangement. Check the variations function to preview the different arrangements and styles.

The piece will slowly render and automatically pause after reaching its final form. You can press Space to Pause/Unpause the piece and let it run longer resulting in more saturated colors.

You can adjust the rendering speed with up/down-arrows or you can also load the page with
'&Speed=*'
at the end of the url to adjust the rendering speed (default = 25) and press S at any time to save an image of any state of the animation.
 
Initial minters will receive 10% royalties.


PLEASE NOTE: 
This piece was developed in and is best viewed in Chrome (100.0.4896.127). Moreover hardware acceleration needs to be enabled in the browser settings. There are still some browsers & devices that struggle with this piece, most notably iOS and Firefox. There is a fallback which is enabled in Firefox and iOS by default that works without hardware acceleration but produces notably different results in texture and color saturation (especially on iOS). You may force the fallback by appending "&noHA=true" to the url in live view and force the original rendering by appending "&forceHA=true" (Note you can combine multiple URL parameters with an "&", eg "www.fxhash.xyz[...]?Speed=50&forceHA=true").
 Please make sure that you have a device and browser capable of rendering this piece before minting.

metadata.name: Southern Gothic #254
metadata.description:
‚ÄúSouthern Gothic‚Äù is my debut release on the fxhash platform. The project is created entirely through code. All copyrights are released to the holder of each image output, even for commercial purposes.

‚ÄúSouthern Gothic‚Äù borrows its name from the literary genre made famous by writers like Flannery O‚ÄôConnor and Carson McCullers. Rather than illustrating a singular setting, the code generates an entire rural townscape, thereby, blurring the boundaries between representation and narrative. The individual scenes are framed frontally with an intentionally flat aesthetic character, referencing traditional folk art of the American South. The absence of human figures within these scenes adds to their overwhelming sense of darkness and forlorn. Observing multiple scenes side-by-side, one may even get the strange feeling that something terrible has happened (or is about to happen) in this rural landscape.

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: We Are Alone Together #439
metadata.description:
We meander through the flows of life, alone but together. This experience ‚Äî an ultimately solitary one ‚Äî is communicated but never truly shared. Our consciousnesses live in a perpetual separated state, alone but together.

############

Display resolution scales with window size. Press ‚Äôh‚Äô (in live mode) to generate a 6000x7500 hi-res image. This may take a few seconds to generate depending on your hardware. Press ‚Äòd‚Äô to redraw the artwork.

Original artwork by perkwerk * made with p5.js * 2022

metadata.name: Dragons #483
metadata.description:
A grid of many lines forming a dragon crafted on paper.
They all have their own personality... Be sure to name and take care of them.

tw: williamapan

metadata.name: Bardez #263
metadata.description:
Bardez is the Armenian word for garden. It is etymologically tied to an ancient word for paradise, but that link goes deeper than etymology. Gardens have always been small pieces of paradise for me, and hearing the word in Armenian triggers a flood of warm memories.

Memories of wandering around my grandfather‚Äôs garden, plucking ripe plums and figs from their branches.
Memories of playing in my parents yard, the scent of jasmine in the summer heat.
Of sun warmed tomatoes in my mom‚Äôs vegetable patch.
The smell of dirt and grass.
Mud on my hands.
Sun on my skin.
Memories of paradise.

I hope you enjoy these gardens I‚Äôve planted, and I hope they remind you of some warm and wonderful memories.
 
Nat Sarkissian






Notes:
 - This piece uses a shader to compute the lighting of the terrain in the first frame. If you don‚Äôt have a graphics card, you may have difficulty running this.

 - Append ‚Äú&mag=N‚Äù to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done. The maximum resolution seems to be limited by what your web browser allows. I have been able to output up to 11140px tall and wide using Firefox, which should be enough detail for prints up to 37x37 inches. I recommend keeping the console open while attempting larger renders. It will show you the progress of the render, and also show you if you have attempted too large a render for your system. N can be any positive whole or decimal number greater than or equal to 1.

 - Finally, collectors at the highest tier will be entitled to a signed print of their edition. For further details and updates, keep an eye on my Twitter (@_NatSarkissian).

metadata.name: 3OHA #41
metadata.description:
This work is a representation of complex systems found in both nature and society. The artwork consists of simple recursively divided cells, showcasing the self-similarity that exists in many structures. The texture of each cell resembles the weave of fabric, emphasizing the interconnected nature of these systems. The patterns and structures generated by the artwork follow simple rules, yet the resulting composition is intricate and complex. This artwork highlights the way that simple elements can combine to form more complex systems, and prompts reflection on the underlying structures that shape our world. The texture which resembles fabric or weaved material is not an afterthought but was more the initial purpose of this work.

HALF OF THE MONEY WILL BE DONATED FOR THE EARTHQUAKE RELIEF FUND.

metadata.name: Ode to Random #74
metadata.description:
This simple minimalist generative token is a tribute to randomness. The underlying grid, the start and end of the colored shapes, the color styles, the transitioning point from order to chaos, are randomized. The names behind the Styles of this token are derived from artists who have greatly inspired me, all or most of whom have incorporated randomness or chaos in their art in one way or another.

The price and number of editions were also chosen using a pseudorandom number generator.

Embrace the random!

Made in p5js
Created December 2021
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #221
metadata.description:
‚ÄúOrdinary Places‚Äù is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becher‚Äôs ‚ÄúWater Tower‚Äù photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruscha‚Äôs ‚Äú26 Gasoline Stations‚Äù photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfather‚Äôs farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: achromat [reissue] #105
metadata.description: Reissue of project #61 that fixes an external dependency issue.

metadata.name: Hashed Cities #242
metadata.description:
This token generates a deterministic set of minimal, abstract buildings of varying widths, heights, transparencies, and patterns, assembling a skyline view of your own unique imaginary city. Each city comes with its own randomized city day.

Each mint has a native setting (Day or Night) which combined with the current time of viewing influences real-time movements of celestial bodies in your mint, e.g. on a mint with the Day setting, the sun will only appear when viewed during the day. The piece will re-render every minute.

The individual strokes of this token feature some of my latest developments of an algorithm that generatively simulates the texture of print imperfections. They are randomized at each render to give it a unique character. Note that depending on the complexity of each mint, some renders may introduce a brief pause. The aesthetics are greatly inspired by plotter art of early computer artists such as 'City Painting' by Grace C. Hertlein.

Made in p5js
Created Nov 2021
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: achromat [reissue] #104
metadata.description: Reissue of project #61 that fixes an external dependency issue.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #583
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. ‚ÄúThe Bugged Tree‚Äù‚Äôs code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren‚Äôt under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there‚Äôs a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan
